ratings.comment: Timur is the way to go for 340!! His lectures are pretty easy going, and it is easy to follow along. His lectures are also recorded, and he posts the notes. Stay on top of the lecture material and you will do just fine

I really like Timur as a person as well as a professor, although his he does have a habit of making some minor mistakes which costed time during lecture, although reading the lecture notes wasn't too bad as his handwriting isn't too bad. He's pretty good out of the choices you have for linear algebra professors.

Professor Yastrzhembskiy is a decent professor, but not very helpful if you ask for clarification. His lectures are difficult to understand, and you will most likely have to rewatch them. He has a nice sense of humor to cheer up the mood. There are biweekly quizzes in the discussion sections, which help prepare you for exams. He is overall okay.

The professor is great, he did everything he can do to let you get a high grade for the test. His notes are really helpful and he is a very kind person. However, the setting of this class is absolutely awful, 76% percent of the grade is the three tests. The real question is difficultly of test in S25 is relatively harder than the previous semester.

He is an amazing teacher who cares a lot about his students. He has a pretty thick Slavic accent, which can make the lecture hard to follow occasionally, but the provided notes worksheets entirely make up for it. The content of his class is very difficult, so I can understand why people struggle with it, but he is always available to help out.

One of the worst professors I have ever had at UW Madison. He doesn't explain concepts clearly at all. I had such a hard time in class even understanding what he was talking about because he doesn't explain his thought process!
